office:text.text:p:
A Constrained Control Problem with Degenerate Coefficients and Degenerate Backward SPDEs with Singular Terminal Condition
We thanks seminar participants at various institutions for valuable comments and suggestions.

Ulrich Horst
TexMaths12§inline§{}^{1}§png§600§FALSE

Jinniao Qiu
TexMaths12§inline§{}^{2}§png§600§FALSE

Qi Zhang
TexMaths12§inline§{}^{3}§png§600§FALSE

We study a constrained optimal control problem allowing for degenerate coefficients. The coefficients can be random and then the value function is described by a degenerate backward stochastic partial differential equation (BSPDE) with singular terminal condition. For this degenerate BSPDE, we prove the existence of the minimal nonnegative solution.

text:note-body.text:p: Department of Mathematics and School of Business and Economics, Humboldt-University of Berlin, Unter den Linden 6, 10099 Berlin, Germany. E-mail: horst@math.hu-berlin.de
Department of Mathematics, Humboldt-University of Berlin, Unter den Linden 6, 10099 Berlin, Germany. E-mail: qiujinn@gmail.com
School of Mathematical Sciences, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, China. E-mail: qzh@fudan.edu.cn

office:text.text:p: AMS Subject Classification: 93E20, 60H15, 91G80
Keywords: stochastic control, degenerate parabolic condition, backward stochastic partial differential equation, portfolio liquidation, singular terminal value.
1Introduction

Let
TexMaths12§inline§T\in(0,\infty)§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§(\Omega,\bar{\mathscr{F}},\mathbb{P})§png§600§FALSE be a probability space equipped with a filtration
TexMaths12§inline§\{\bar{\mathscr{F}}_{t}\}_{0\leq t\leq T}§png§600§FALSE which satisfies the usual conditions. The probability space carries an
TexMaths12§inline§m§png§600§FALSE-dimensional Brownian motion
TexMaths12§inline§W§png§600§FALSE and an independent point process
TexMaths12§inline§\tilde{J}§png§600§FALSE on a non-empty Borel set
TexMaths12§inline§\mathcal{Z}\subset\mathbb{R}^{l}§png§600§FALSE with characteristic measure
TexMaths12§inline§\mu(dz)§png§600§FALSE. We endow the set
TexMaths12§inline§\mathcal{Z}§png§600§FALSE with its Borel
TexMaths12§inline§\sigma§png§600§FALSE-algebra
TexMaths12§inline§\mathscr{Z}§png§600§FALSE and denote by
TexMaths12§inline§\pi(dt,dz)§png§600§FALSE the associated Poisson random measure. The filtration generated by
TexMaths12§inline§W§png§600§FALSE, together with all
TexMaths12§inline§\mathbb{P}§png§600§FALSE null sets, is denoted by
TexMaths12§inline§\{\mathscr{F}_{t}\}_{t\geq 0}§png§600§FALSE. The predictable
TexMaths12§inline§\sigma§png§600§FALSE-algebra on
TexMaths12§inline§\Omega\times[0,+\infty)§png§600§FALSE corresponding to
TexMaths12§inline§\{\mathscr{F}_{t}\}_{t\geq 0}§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§\{\bar{\mathscr{F}}_{t}\}_{t\geq 0}§png§600§FALSE are denoted by
TexMaths12§inline§\mathscr{P}§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§\bar{\mathscr{P}}§png§600§FALSE, respectively.
In this paper we address the following stochastic optimal control problem with constraints:
subject to

The real-valued process
TexMaths12§inline§(x_{t})_{t\in[0,T]}§png§600§FALSE is the state process. It is governed by a pair of controls
TexMaths12§inline§(\xi,\rho)§png§600§FALSE. The
TexMaths12§inline§m§png§600§FALSE-dimensional process
TexMaths12§inline§(y_{t})_{t\in[0,T]}§png§600§FALSE is uncontrolled. We sometimes write
TexMaths12§inline§x^{s,x,\xi,\rho}_{t}§png§600§FALSE for
TexMaths12§inline§0\leq s\leq t\leq T§png§600§FALSE to indicate the dependence of the state process on the control
TexMaths12§inline§(\xi,\rho)§png§600§FALSE, the initial time
TexMaths12§inline§s§png§600§FALSE and initial state
TexMaths12§inline§x\in\mathbb{R}§png§600§FALSE. Likewise, we sometimes write
TexMaths12§inline§y^{s,y}_{t}§png§600§FALSE to indicate the dependence on the initial time and state. The set of admissible controls consists of all pairs
TexMaths12§inline§(\xi,\rho)\in\mathcal{L}^{2}_{\bar{\mathscr{F}}}(0,T)\times\mathcal{L}^{2}_{% \bar{\mathscr{F}}}(0,T;L^{2}(\mathcal{Z}))§png§600§FALSE such that
TexMaths12§inline§x_{T}=0§png§600§FALSE a.s..

Control problems of above form arise in models of optimal portfolio liquidation. In such models
TexMaths12§inline§x_{t}§png§600§FALSE denotes the portfolio an investor holds at time
TexMaths12§inline§t\in[0,T]§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\xi_{t}§png§600§FALSE is the rate at which the stock is purchased or sold in a regular exchange at that time,
TexMaths12§inline§x_{T}=0§png§600§FALSE is the liquidation constraint,
TexMaths12§inline§\rho_{t}§png§600§FALSE describes the number of stocks placed in a crossing network,
TexMaths12§inline§\pi§png§600§FALSE governs the order execution in the crossing network and
TexMaths12§inline§y_{t}§png§600§FALSE is a stochastic factor, often a benchmark price process, against which the cost of the liquidation strategy
TexMaths12§inline§(\xi,\rho)§png§600§FALSE is benchmarked.
The cost functional is assumed to be of the quadratic form:
and introduce the associated value function:

We refer to and references therein for a detailed discussion of portfolio liquidation problems and an interpretation of the coefficients
TexMaths12§inline§\eta,\lambda§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§\gamma§png§600§FALSE.

In a Markovian framework where all coefficients are deterministic functions of the control and state variables the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation turns out to be a deterministic nonlinear parabolic partial differential equation (PDE) with a singularity at the terminal time; see for details. Non-Markovian control problems with pre-specified terminal values have been studied in recent papers by Ankirchner, Jeanblanc, and Kruse and Graewe, Horst and Qiu . The former represented the value function in terms of a nonlinear backward stochastic differential equation (BSDE). While BSDEs are tailor-made to study non-Markovian control problems, the optimal control is of an open-loop form and hence it does not give the precise dependence of the optimal control on the factor process
TexMaths12§inline§(y_{t})_{t\in[0,T]}§png§600§FALSE.

The BSPDE-approach of Graewe et al. is more general. They construct the optimal control in feedback form assuming that there exists another independent
TexMaths12§inline§n§png§600§FALSE-dimensional Brownian motion
TexMaths12§inline§B§png§600§FALSE s.t.

that the coefficients
TexMaths12§inline§b§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\sigma§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\bar{\sigma}§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\lambda§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\gamma§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§\eta§png§600§FALSE are measurable with respect to the filtration
TexMaths12§inline§\mathscr{F}§png§600§FALSE generated by
TexMaths12§inline§W§png§600§FALSE, and that
TexMaths12§inline§\bar{\sigma}§png§600§FALSE satisfies the strict non-degeneracy condition. We extend their results to the degenerate case and also allow all coefficients to depend on all sources of randomness. This is important form an application point of view, as the strict separation of the two sources of randomness in (1.5) is not always natural and/or easy to satisfy.
The constrained optimal control problem (1.1) can be formally written as an unconstrained one:
subject to

Inspired by Peng’s seminal work on non-Markovian stochastic optimal control and in view of the linear-quadratic structure of the cost functional, the dynamic programming principle suggests that the value function is of the form

where
TexMaths12§inline§u§png§600§FALSE is the first component of the pair
TexMaths12§inline§(u,\psi)§png§600§FALSE that satisfies formally the following backward stochastic partial differential equation (BSPDE) with singular terminal condition:
where

BSPDEs were first introduced by Bensoussan as the adjoint equations of forward SPDEs. They have since been extensively used to study a wide range of problems in pure and applied probability ranging from stochastic maximum principles to optimal control under partial information and from optimal stopping to hedging in incomplete financial markets .

To the best of our knowledge degenerate BSPDEs with singular terminal values have never been studied in the literature before, not even in the Markovian case. Due to the degeneracy of the diffusion coefficient, no generalized Itô-Kunita formula for the random filed
TexMaths12§inline§u§png§600§FALSE satisfying the BSPDE (1.7) in the distributional sense is available. To prove the verification theorem we appeal instead to the link between degenerate BSPDEs and forward-backward stochastic differential equations (FBSDEs). Drawing on recent results on degenerate BSPDEs , we first prove that the BSPDE resulting from our control problem but with finite terminal condition has a sufficient regular solution.

Subsequently, we establish a comparison principle for degenerate BSPDEs from which we deduce that the solutions to BSPDEs with finite terminal values increase with the terminal values. To verify the limit of a sequence of BSPDEs with increasing terminal values is a solution to our BSPDE (1.7) requires a gradient estimate. Such an estimate is not needed in the non-degenerate case. The non-degenerate case only requires a growth condition on
TexMaths12§inline§u_{t}§png§600§FALSE near the terminal time while the degenerate case requires an additional strong integrability condition of the gradient
TexMaths12§inline§Du_{t}§png§600§FALSE.

The gradient estimate for a solution to a degenerate BSPDE generally depends on its gradient at terminal time. In our case, the terminal value of the BSPDE is singular and hence it does in no obvious way characterize the gradient. Instead, we derive our gradient estimate from the gradient estimates of the approximating sequence. Our estimate seems new even in the Markovian case. Along with the gradient estimate, an explicit asymptotic estimate for the solution of BSPDE near the terminal time is given. Finally, using the Itô formula for the square norm of the positive part of the solutions for BSPDEs, we prove that the obtained solution is the minimal nonnegative one.

This remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce some auxiliary notation and state our main result. The verification theorem is proved in Section 3. In Section 4, we show that the BSPDE (1.7) has a solution if the terminal value is finite. As a byproduct, the comparison principle is established for general semi-linear degenerate BSPDEs. Finally, in Section 5, we construct a solution for our BSPDE which is subsequently proved to be the minimal nonnegative one.
2Assumptions and Main Result

Throughout this paper, we use the following notation.

TexMaths12§inline§k=0§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§H^{0,p}(\Pi;\mathbb{R})\triangleq L^{p}(\Pi;\mathbb{R})§png§600§FALSE. Moreover,

We establish existence of a solution to (1.7) under the following regularity conditions on the random coefficients. The first two assumptions are standard and adopted throughout. The third is particular to the degenerate case. It allows for sufficient integrality of the derivative of the value function. It is satisfied if, for instant
TexMaths12§inline§\eta_{T}(y)§png§600§FALSE is a constant.

We now state our main results. The following theorem is a summary of Theorems 3.3, 5.1 and 5.5.

text:p.text:span:
Under Conditions (H.1)–(H.3) the BSPDE (1.7) admits a minimal nonnegative solution
TexMaths12§inline§(u,\psi)§png§600§FALSE with
TexMaths12§inline§u\in C^{w}_{\mathscr{F}}(0,t;H^{1,2}_{loc})§png§600§FALSE,

TexMaths12§inline§t\in[0,T)§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\bar{u}_{t}\geq u_{t}§png§600§FALSE almost everywhere in
TexMaths12§inline§\mathbb{R}^{d}§png§600§FALSE. For this solution, given any

office:text.text:p:
If all the coefficients
TexMaths12§inline§b,\sigma,\lambda,\eta,\gamma§png§600§FALSE are deterministic, then the optimal control problem is Markovian and the BSPDE (1.7) reduces to the following parabolic PDE:

where
TexMaths12§inline§\sigma_{t}\sigma^{*}_{t}§png§600§FALSE could be degenerate. Under (H.1)–(H.3), this PDE holds in the distributional (or weak) sense. As such, our results are new even in the Markovian case.
3The verification theorem

In order to prepare the proof of the verification theorem we now recall selected results on degenerate semi-linear BSPDEs and their connections to FBSDEs from . The link between FBSDEs and BSPDEs is key. It will allow us to compute the dynamics of the process
TexMaths12§inline§u_{t}(y_{t})|x_{t}|^{2}§png§600§FALSE.

text:p.text:span:
Assume that the coefficients
TexMaths12§inline§b§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§\sigma§png§600§FALSE satisfy (H.1) and (H.2) and that
TexMaths12§inline§\varrho:\Omega\times[0,T]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{m}§png§600§FALSE satisfies the same conditions as
TexMaths12§inline§b§png§600§FALSE. Let
TexMaths12§inline§f:\Omega\times[0,T]\times\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}§png§600§FALSE satisfy:
is a.s. continuous with respect to
and it holds almost surely that

TexMaths12§inline§\mathscr{A}§png§600§FALSE for which the corresponding state process is monotone.

text:p.text:span:

TexMaths12§inline§(\xi,\rho)\in\mathcal{L}^{2}_{\bar{\mathscr{F}}}(0,T)\times\mathcal{L}^{2}_{% \bar{\mathscr{F}}}(0,T;L^{2}(\mathcal{Z}))§png§600§FALSE, there exists a corresponding admissible control pair

TexMaths12§inline§(t,x)§png§600§FALSE and the control
TexMaths12§inline§(\hat{\rho},\hat{\xi})§png§600§FALSE, such that:

office:text.text:p: We are now prepared to state and prove the verification theorem. The key assumption is that the gradient of the solution to our BSDE is sufficiently regular so that it can be represented as an FBSDE.

text:p.text:span:

TexMaths12§inline§p>2d+2§png§600§FALSE, and almost surely

coincides with the value function (1.4). Moreover, the optimal feedback control is given by (2.3).

TexMaths12§inline§(t,y)\in[0,T)\times\mathbb{R}^{d}§png§600§FALSE, due to Sobolev’s embedding theorem.

Second, the BSPDE (1.7) is equivalent to the BSPDE (2.2) whose driver satisfies the assumptions of Theorem 3.1. Thus, if we take

TexMaths12§inline§\theta u_{\tau}(y)§png§600§FALSE as the terminal condition, then this BSPDE satisfies the assumptions of Theorem 3.1 on
TexMaths12§inline§[0,\tau]§png§600§FALSE.

TexMaths12§inline§u_{t}(y_{t}^{0,y})|x_{t}^{0,x;\xi,\rho}|^{2}§png§600§FALSE. Using Lemma 3.2 one can now apply the exact same arguments as in the proof of to deduce that:

4A Comparison Principle and Solutions of Truncated BSPDEs

In view of the verification theorem it remains to prove that the BSPDE (1.7) has a solution with particular properties. Since Theorem 3.1 does not apply to this equation, we first establish a comparison principle for degenerate BSPDEs from which we then deduce that a solution to (1.7) can be obtained a the limit of a sequence of solutions to BSPDEs with finite terminal values. The comparison principle is essentially a corollary of the following Itô formula for the square norm of the positive part of the solution to a BSPDE.

text:p.text:span:
Let
TexMaths12§inline§u\in\mathcal{L}^{2}_{\mathscr{F}}(0,T;H^{1,2})§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§G\in L^{2}(\Omega,\mathscr{F}_{T};L^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d}))§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\zeta,f,g\in\mathcal{L}^{2}_{\mathscr{F}}(0,T;L^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d}))§png§600§FALSE, and assume that for arbitrary
TexMaths12§inline§\varphi\in C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})§png§600§FALSE,

TexMaths12§inline§L^{2}(\Omega,\mathscr{F};C([0,T];H^{0,2}))§png§600§FALSE and by one has both

office:text.text:p: We are now ready to state and prove a comparison principle for nonlinear degenerate BSPDEs.

text:p.text:span:
Assume that the coefficients
TexMaths12§inline§b§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\sigma§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\varrho§png§600§FALSE and the pairs of initial conditions and driver
TexMaths12§inline§(G,f)§png§600§FALSE and

TexMaths12§inline§(u,\psi)§png§600§FALSE and

TexMaths12§inline§(u,\psi+\sigma^{*}Du)§png§600§FALSE and

TexMaths12§inline§\mathcal{L}^{2}(0,T;H^{1,2})\times\mathcal{L}^{2}(0,T;H^{1,2})§png§600§FALSE. If

for almost every
TexMaths12§inline§(\omega,t,y)\in\Omega\times[0,T]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}§png§600§FALSEthen we have almost surely that

office:text.text:p:
We put

Let us denote the entries of the diffusion matrix

Hence, Lemma 4.1 yields a constant

Thus, an application of Gronwall inequality leads to:

Next, we show that the BSPDE (2.2) has a unique solution if the terminal value is finite. To this end, let

We note that by introducing the function
TexMaths12§inline§\hat{F}§png§600§FALSE, the bounded solution to (4.1) is nonnegative.

text:p.text:span:
Assume (H.1) and (H.2). For each

TexMaths12§inline§(v^{N},\zeta^{N})§png§600§FALSE with

such that

office:text.text:p:
To prove existence of a solution, we truncate the quadratic term in
TexMaths12§inline§\hat{F}§png§600§FALSE. More precisely, let
and

For each
TexMaths12§inline§M\in\mathbb{N}§png§600§FALSE, we know from Theorem 3.1 that the BSPDE

Changing the coefficients

is a solution, and the comparison principle stated in Proposition 4.2 yields:

Thus, for all sufficiently large

TexMaths12§inline§v^{N,M}§png§600§FALSE and hence the pair

TexMaths12§inline§M§png§600§FALSE and is in fact a solution to (4.1). Uniqueness of solutions follows from similar arguments. ∎
Since the solution of (4.2) is bounded, we deduce from Proposition 4.2 a comparison principle for the BSPDE (4.1).

text:p.text:span:
Assume that the coefficients of the BSPDE (4.1) satisfy Conditions (H.1)-(H.2) and denote the solution by

with

If

A similar statement holds for the reverse inequalities.

office:text.text:p: 5Existence of a minimal nonnegative solution to (1.7)
In this section we establish the existence of a solution for BSPDE (1.7). More precisely, we prove the following theorem.

text:p.text:span:
Under Conditions (H.1)-(H.3), for any
TexMaths12§inline§p\in[2,p_{0})§png§600§FALSE BSPDE (1.7) has a solution
TexMaths12§inline§(u,\psi)§png§600§FALSE such that for some
TexMaths12§inline§\alpha\in(1,2)§png§600§FALSE,

with two constants
TexMaths12§inline§c_{0}>0§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§c_{1}>0§png§600§FALSE.

office:text.text:p:
The proof is split in several steps. The idea is to identify a solution as a accumulation point of a convex combination subsequence of the sequence of solutions to the BSPDE (4.1). For
TexMaths12§inline§p_{1}\in[2,p_{0})§png§600§FALSE this BSPDE has a unique solution
TexMaths12§inline§(v^{N},\zeta^{N})§png§600§FALSE, due to Proposition 4.3. The sequence
TexMaths12§inline§\{v^{N}\}§png§600§FALSE increases in
TexMaths12§inline§N§png§600§FALSE, due to Corollary 4.4 and hence converges to some limit
TexMaths12§inline§v§png§600§FALSE. We show below that
TexMaths12§inline§v§png§600§FALSE satisfies the growth condition (5.1).

The challenge is to establish the existence of a norm-bound and hence an accumulation point of the sequence
TexMaths12§inline§\{Dv^{N}\}§png§600§FALSE. Due to the singularity of the terminal value such an estimate cannot be obtained from the BSPDE (2.2) directly. Instead we show in Section 5.1.1 that under (H.3) the norm of the gradients essentially only depend on
TexMaths12§inline§\eta§png§600§FALSE. We then establish our existence of solutions result in Section 5.1.2.
5.1Existence of a solution

As a first step toward the proof of our existence result, we show that the limiting function
TexMaths12§inline§v§png§600§FALSE satisfies the growth condition (5.1). To this end, we replace the coefficients
TexMaths12§inline§(\lambda,\gamma,\eta)§png§600§FALSE by their lower bound
TexMaths12§inline§(0,0,\kappa)§png§600§FALSE and upper bound
TexMaths12§inline§(\Lambda,+\infty,\Lambda)§png§600§FALSE, respectively, deduce from Proposition 4.3 that the resulting BSPDEs have unique solutions, verify by direct computation that respective solutions are given by
TexMaths12§inline§(\hat{u}^{N},0)§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§(\tilde{u}^{N},0)§png§600§FALSE, respectively, where
and then apply the comparison principle to deduce that almost surely:
Since
we see that
5.1.1Gradient estimate

Our next goal is to establish a uniform bound for the sequence
TexMaths12§inline§\{Dv^{N}\}§png§600§FALSE in
TexMaths12§inline§H^{1,p}§png§600§FALSE. As a byproduct we obtain a bound for the sequence
TexMaths12§inline§\{\zeta^{N}+\sigma^{*}Dv^{N}\}§png§600§FALSE in
TexMaths12§inline§\mathcal{L}^{2}(0,T;H^{1,2})§png§600§FALSE. The bound given in Theorem 3.1 (ii) depends on the Lipschitz constant of the driver of the BSPDE. In our case, this means that it depends on the function
TexMaths12§inline§v^{N}§png§600§FALSE, due to the quadratic dependence of the driver on
TexMaths12§inline§v^{N}§png§600§FALSE. The following corollary provides a better estimate. The estimates in Theorem 3.1 are obtained by applying Itô formulas directly (see ); hence we can derive the estimates as well as from the monotonicity of the drift for BSPDE (3.1) instead of the Lipschitz condition. The detailed proof is omitted; it is standard but cumbersome.

text:p.text:span: Assume the same hypothesis of Theorem 3.1 with

for some
TexMaths12§inline§p\in[2,\infty)§png§600§FALSE. Let
TexMaths12§inline§(u,\phi)§png§600§FALSE be the solution of BSPDE (3.1) in Theorem 3.1. If there exist constant
TexMaths12§inline§L_{1}§png§600§FALSE and function
TexMaths12§inline§g\in\mathcal{L}^{p}_{\mathscr{F}}(0,T;H^{0,p})\cap\mathcal{L}^{2}_{\mathscr{F}% }(0,T;H^{0,2})§png§600§FALSE such that for almost every
TexMaths12§inline§(\omega,s,y)\in\Omega\times[0,T]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}§png§600§FALSE,

office:text.text:p: We now proceed with the gradient estimate. Since we are mainly interested in the behavior of the gradient near the terminal time, we put

and notice that (5.2) holds with
TexMaths12§inline§\kappa§png§600§FALSE replaced by
TexMaths12§inline§\kappa_{1}§png§600§FALSE on
TexMaths12§inline§[T_{0},T]§png§600§FALSE.

text:p.text:span:

TexMaths12§inline§p_{1}\in[2,p_{0})§png§600§FALSE such that

office:text.text:p:
A direct computation shows that the sequence
TexMaths12§inline§\{(Q^{N},\xi^{N})\}§png§600§FALSE is a solution to the BSPDE:

TexMaths12§inline§L_{1}<\infty§png§600§FALSE independent of
TexMaths12§inline§N§png§600§FALSE and a function
TexMaths12§inline§g^{N}\in\mathcal{L}^{p}(T_{1},T;H^{0,p})§png§600§FALSE which satisfies

TexMaths12§inline§\partial_{y^{i}}Q_{t}^{N}(y)\partial_{y^{i}}(f^{2}_{N}-f^{1}_{N})(s,y)§png§600§FALSE where

To this end, notice that

TexMaths12§inline§y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}§png§600§FALSE one has:

Thus, for any
TexMaths12§inline§t\in[T_{1},T]§png§600§FALSE, we have
where

Since

This proves the assertion. ∎

text:p.text:span:
The previous lemma along with an application of Theorem 3.1 to the time interval
TexMaths12§inline§[0,T_{1}]§png§600§FALSE, leads to the desired gradient estimate:

office:text.text:p: 5.1.2The solution

The estimate (5.5) allows us to extract a subsequence

TexMaths12§inline§(Q^{N_{k}},\xi^{N_{k}},\xi^{N_{k}}+\sigma^{*}DQ^{N_{k}})§png§600§FALSE that converges strongly in corresponding spaces. Therefore, it is easy to check that
TexMaths12§inline§(Q,\xi)§png§600§FALSE solves:

By Theorem 3.1 and Proposition 4.2,

TexMaths12§inline§(Q,\xi)§png§600§FALSE, such that

Recovering

TexMaths12§inline§(u,\psi)\,{\triangleq}\,\theta^{-1}(v,\zeta)§png§600§FALSE we see that
TexMaths12§inline§(u,\psi)§png§600§FALSE solves (1.7) and that

Moreover, (5.1) holds with
TexMaths12§inline§c_{0}={\kappa}e^{-\mu(\mathcal{Z})T}§png§600§FALSE and
TexMaths12§inline§c_{1}=\Lambda e^{2T}§png§600§FALSE. Since
TexMaths12§inline§p_{1}\in[2,p_{0})§png§600§FALSE is arbitrary, this completes the proof of Theorem 5.1.
5.2Minimal solution
We close our analysis with the following result on minimal nonnegative solutions to our BSPDE (1.7).

text:p.text:span:
Under Conditions (H.1)–(H.3), the solution
TexMaths12§inline§(u,\psi)§png§600§FALSE to (1.7) constructed in the proof of Theorem 5.1 is the minimal nonnegative solution. That is, if
TexMaths12§inline§(\tilde{u},\tilde{\psi})§png§600§FALSE is a solution of (1.7) satisfying

and if
TexMaths12§inline§\tilde{u}_{t}(y)\geq 0§png§600§FALSE for almost every
TexMaths12§inline§(\omega,t,y)\in\Omega\times[0,T)\times\mathbb{R}^{d}§png§600§FALSE, then almost surely for every
TexMaths12§inline§t\in[0,T)§png§600§FALSE,
TexMaths12§inline§\tilde{u}_{t}\geq u_{t}§png§600§FALSE almost everywhere in
TexMaths12§inline§\mathbb{R}^{d}§png§600§FALSE.

office:text.text:p:
Let

For this, we put

for every non-negative any

TexMaths12§inline§C<\infty§png§600§FALSE such that for
TexMaths12§inline§0\leq t<\tau<T§png§600§FALSE:

with a constant

TexMaths12§inline§t§png§600§FALSE. Since

Proposition 4.3 allows us to integrate

[7] K. Du, J. Qiu, and S. Tang,
TexMaths12§inline§\textrm{L}^{p}§png§600§FALSE theory for super-parabolic backward stochastic partial differential equations in the whole space, Appl. Math. Optim., 65 (2011), pp. 175–219.

TexMaths12§inline§\textrm{W}^{m,p}§png§600§FALSE-solution (

[9] K. Du and Q. Zhang, Semi-linear degenerate backward stochastic partial differential equations and associated forward-backward stochastic differential equations, Stoch. Process. Appl., 123 (2013), pp. 1616–1637.

[11] P. Forsyth, J. Kennedy, S. Tse, and H. Windcliff, Optimal trade execution: A mean quadratic variation approach, J. Econ. Dyn. Control, 36 (2012), pp. 1971–1991.

[18] P. Kratz and T. Schöneborn, Portfolio liquidation in dark pools in continuous time, Math. Financ., (2013).
